faqs.question: Can foreigners buy property in Spain?
faqs.answer: Yes, foreigners can purchase property in Spain. There are no restrictions on non-residents buying residential property. You will need a Spanish tax identification number (NIE) and must comply with standard purchase procedures. Our team can guide you through the legal requirements and connect you with English-speaking solicitors experienced in international property purchases.

faqs.question: What are the costs of buying property in Spain?
faqs.answer: Beyond the purchase price, typical costs include transfer tax (6-10% depending on region), notary fees (0.5-1%), property registration fees (0.1-0.5%), and legal fees for your solicitor (1-2%). In Murcia, transfer tax is approximately 8%. These are estimated ranges, and exact costs vary by individual circumstances. We recommend obtaining a detailed cost breakdown from your legal advisor.

faqs.question: Do I need a visa to buy property in Spain?
faqs.answer: Purchasing property in Spain does not automatically grant residency or a visa. However, Spain offers various visa options including the Golden Visa (for significant property investments), Non-Lucrative Visa, and Digital Nomad Visa. Each has specific requirements. We recommend consulting with Spanish immigration specialists to understand which options suit your circumstances and to navigate the application process.

faqs.question: How much are property taxes in Spain?
faqs.answer: Annual property taxes in Spain include the IBI (property tax), typically 0.4-1.1% of cadastral value, and may include refuse collection and other municipal charges. For rental properties, you'll pay income tax on rental earnings (rates vary by income level). Capital gains tax applies if you sell at a profit. These rates vary by location and individual circumstances. Consult a Spanish tax advisor for precise calculations based on your specific property and situation.
